div1.p: Lazear writes about a long hiking trip and the Alsace-Lorraine.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 24, 1890
div1.p:
Here we are
in Strassburg. We left Frei-
burg on Friday morning and
crossed the Rhine that
afternoon, stayed that
night in Sundhausen and
reached here last night
making nearly sixty miles
in the two days. Unfortunately
Norris's shoes gave out at
Freiburg and he had to
wear new ones. His heels
became blistered and last
night they were beginning
to fester. This made it
necessary for him to lay
off for a while so he will
go by rail to Heidelburg
and I will walk from
here to there alone and
and we will start from
there together on Thursday
or Friday. I will go as
for as Baden-Baden to-
morrow, the next day to
Carlsruhe and the next
to Heidelburg. I stayed
over here to-day (Sunday) to
see the town which is
an extremely interesting
one. The roofs of the houses
are steep and they have
Dormer windows, sometimes
three or four rows of them.
The town is surrounded by
high walls and fortifications
and can only be entered by
certain gates. You would
think that a war was
going on, and the enormous
number of soldiers adds to
this appearance. I went
to the famous cathedral this
morning and it is really
a remarkably fine building.
I heard the and saw the clock
“go off” at twelve o'clock. It is
a remarkable mechanism
but with its crowing cock
and puppet figures, it seems
rediculous in a fine
church. I went up into
the tower where there is a
fine view of the city with
the Vosges and Ural moun-
tains and the Black Forest.
Our walk from Freiburg
has all been in beautiful
country and we had good
chance to study the life
of the peasants. At Sundhausen
where we slept Friday night
we had a very pleasant
evening. While we were eating
dinner a German who was
staying there came in and
afterwards an Alsacian
and a German soldier. We
sat there and talked from
until eleven o'clock and
had a jolly time besides
getting good practice in
German. The German was a
very intelligent man and
knew some English. However
we talked altogether in
German and at only used
his knowledge of English for
the sake of comparing the
two languages. A great
many of the scenes in the
country reminded me of
Millet's paintings. The people
do not live in scattered
houses like our farm-houses
but they are all gathered
together in villages.
We saw them gathering
and beating hemp. And
much to my surprize we
we saw a great deal
of tobacco and Indian corn
growing. Of course the
grape is the chief product.
The Markgräfler wine is grown
in Baden near Freiburg.
The language here is very
peculiar. Most of the people speak both
French and German while some speak
only French and some only German.
The signs on the street are in both
languages. I think the real Germans
on the other side of the river are a
more intelligent race than these
Alsacians.

I am now in excellent trim for
walking. The first soreness and stiffness
has worn of and I can go on walking
until the muscles tire. My feet
have not troubled me at all.

I feel lost without getting any
letters. I could have ordered them
sent here but I was afraid I would
not be allowed to come in without
a passport. I find that it is only
in entering Alsace from France that
they are strict. The Germans are anxious
to cut off intercourse between Alsace
and France as much as possible
in order to Germanize the province.
